Change has been successfully merged
Minor feedback on the background and references. Otherwise, agree with the direction.

CPER stands for Common Platform Error Record and is defined as an industry standard in the UEFI Specification [1], with CPU ISA specific definitions for Arm64, x64, Itanium, and IA32.

In addition to Redfish, there is a proposed DMTF interface for sending CPER log events to the BMC using MCTP/PLDM [2], which is proposed to be added a future version of DMTF DSP0248 [3].

[1] https://uefi.org/specs/UEFI/2.10/Apx_N_Common_Platform_Error_Record.html
[2] https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/PMCI_CPEREvent_Proposal_v3.pdf
[3] https://www.dmtf.org/dsp/DSP0248
Implemented your text word for word in the various sections.
This link is for an older version of the SBMR specification. A better link to refer to is https://developer.arm.com/documentation/den0069/latest/ , which contains the latest SBMR 2.0 specification.
Updated.
Thank you Ed!
Sounds like a good feature to have in OpenBMC.
Long term, would these CPER's come down via phosphor-host-ipmi or somewhere else?
I suspect it very much depends on the architecture of the system you're building.  There are definitions for IPMI KCS, PLDM, and SSIF, so I think any of those could be added.

I am not sure anywhere else using CPER, except ARM SBMR https://developer.arm.com/documentation/den0069/latest/ specified at:
- Section C.2.2 for IPMI command to send CPER Error record to the BMC. This is an IPMI command so I think it should be implemented in phosphor-host-ipmid.
- Section C.3.2 for Redfish RAS message format. Look like https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/62581 and https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/55839 provide support it (but still need some other application to get CPER data and create log entry)

AMD also uses CPER format data by RAS application. See https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/68440
for details. Currently RAS application creates CPER records , and amd custom extrenal tools used for process CPER data .

@Andrew, does that get your question answered?  There's several architectures, one might include phosphor-host-ipmi.  If you'd like me to include those maintainers on this design, I will, but I'm not sure it's necessary for approving the repo.
I'm good
nit: debug
Done

I have a few nitpicks around style and formatting, hence the CR-1 just to get them cleaned up. I also have some reservations around putting libcper under the OpenBMC org given its utility to other projects[^1], but given it needs to be hosted somewhere, I'm not against it either.

[^1]: libmctp and libpldm could also live outside the OpenBMC org

Happy to have that discussion if we think there's a better alternative for hosting this.  My thought process here is that pretty much all other alternatives that I ran through were worse than just a shared repo in OpenBMC.

My requirements are largely to put this somewhere that:
1. Has an existing CI setup.
2. Has an existing code contribution and leadership model for Apache2 software.
3. Has coding standards we can code to.
4. Is a recognized authority such that we can pull this into both an EDK2 build as well as an OpenBMC build.

My immediate thoughts for orgs were essentially this list:

Arm gitlab
github.com/edtanous/libcper
github.com/Nvidia/libcper
github.com/DMTF
github.com/tianocore/edk2
linux Kernel

But each of them fails at least one of the requirements above, except OpenBmc, hence why I landed on this design doc.
What is meant by 'Second' here? It doesn't seem to make sense to me.

Given this is a markdown document, can we please use valid markdown link syntax for references?

For the record I'm reviewing via [the gitiles](https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/docs/+/58816b185705dcadc54ef49fe0a7528ee394bc88/designs/cper-records.md) rendering of the document. The way things are structured at the moment makes the rendered referencing a bit ugly.
This is a typo left from a restructuring of the doc.  Will fix in next revision.

> Given this is a markdown document, can we please use valid markdown link syntax for references?
> 
> For the record I'm reviewing via [the gitiles](https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/docs/+/58816b185705dcadc54ef49fe0a7528ee394bc88/designs/cper-records.md) rendering of the document. The way things are structured at the moment makes the rendered referencing a bit ugly.


ACK.  Will fix.  Just to be clear, you're talking about the rendering of the actual link list at the end?
Removed "Second" and reworked this sentence.

> Just to be clear, you're talking about the rendering of the actual link list at the end?

Yep.
Done
"added in a"
fixed.

Can we get someone from the ARM CLA to do the first push into the repository?  Right now their code is licensed with Apache 2, which if we fork it we can continue down that path fine.  One of the advantages the CLA gives us is if we ever need to relicense in the future (for example an "Apache 3" due to new legal developments) we can.

> Can we get someone from the ARM CLA to do the first push into the repository?  Right now their code is licensed with Apache 2, which if we fork it we can continue down that path fine.  One of the advantages the CLA gives us is if we ever need to relicense in the future (for example an "Apache 3" due to new legal developments) we can.

Is this something we've enforced elsewhere?  If so, we should ideally get that codified with LF in something we can point people to.  I didn't think the CLA itself gave us that capability, but I'm not a lawyer.

With that said, in the context of this design, Samer, is the actual push something you can do if this repo gets approved?  Or is there someone from ARM that you can add to your CLA that can do this?

> 
> With that said, in the context of this design, Samer, is the actual push something you can do if this repo gets approved?  Or is there someone from ARM that you can add to your CLA that can do this?

John Chung on CC is on the Arm CLA, and can do this once the repo is approved.
The "Grant of Copyright License" (2) section covers this relicensing.
ACK.  Closing this as I think we have the original concern addressed.  John will push the initial code.  Feel free to reopen if there are still concerns here.
Can we use a list (either bullet or numbered) for the requirements given they seemed to be formatted that way?
Some of them were multi-line and multi-sentence, which is why I didn't go with bulleted list, but sure, I can make that change.
Changed to a list.

This seems vague enough to not be satisfied.  Who determines what is "decoded" and what isn't?  Aren't there almost always details at a hardware level that only the original vendor has?

How does `libcper` on its own satisfy this?  Does it just generate a string?  This is probably out of scope for now, but it seems like we need some way to eventually populate a LogEntry in Redfish?

> This seems vague enough to not be satisfied.  Who determines what is "decoded" and what isn't?


In terms of the justification for the library, I figured this was enough.  I expected that the answer to "how decoded is decoded" is decided as we develop the repository;  I intentionally made it vauge because what exists only implements basic struct level unpacking of errors and mapping to strings.


>  Aren't there almost always details at a hardware level that only the original vendor has?

That might be true depending on how secret a vendors implementation is, but is there something we can do in this design that make that more clear?

> 
> How does `libcper` on its own satisfy this?  Does it just generate a string?  This is probably out of scope for now, but it seems like we need some way to eventually populate a LogEntry in Redfish?

Yes, for sure, and I think I wrote exactly that later on in the doc;

> I expected that the answer to "how decoded is decoded" is decided as we develop the repository

Are there cases where one system vendor has a different opinion in how much should be decoded?  As in, they might want to hide details of their system.  Is this something we care about?

> Are there cases where one system vendor has a different opinion in how much should be decoded?

I think that's covered by CPER records having different UIDs?  Presumably if they wanted a different decoding, they should define a new UID?  I suspect as we dive into this more, we'll have to come up with compile-time policies around filtering so that people can do what they want for their policy.

UIDs are defined by a chip vendor though where I was referring to a system vendor?

I don't think this is a blocker.

I thought UIDs were determined by BIOS vendor more than system vendor (I'm probably mistaken), but agreed, I don't really see this as a blocker;  I don't have a full line of sight on what the solution is, but I'd be really surprised if whatever solution we come up with ended up being a matter of contention.

Does that mean we should change "shall" to "should"? ;)

My original point here was that the sentence seems either unable to be fulfilled or ill-defined in order to never be satisfied.  What does it mean to "read decoded CPER records"?

I guess the implementation of libcper is the final arbitration on how decoded is decoded?

I had assumed that libcper would have some level of flags/config options/API that would allow getting the various decode levels folks need.  I really suspect the needs aren't that varied amongst users, but who knows.  If there's specific requirements wording that I can put in this design that would help make this clear, I can put it in, but I'd rather we just handle it as a living "as you need features, add the modes you need." basis.

I wordsmithed this a little to make it about decoding binary.  I intentionally left the output format somewhat vauge because what exists in libcper today goes to Json.  OpenBMC would likely need to go to dbus, so really we just need a place where we can share a registry of the CPER UIDs and structs that we can then use in other places.

Isn't this requirement related to PLDM or IPMI based support for CPER? libcper provides more of a decoding logic. Do we need to rephrase it to something like "BMC should be able to decode CPER records from ARM CPU"?
I changed to "receive and decode", but other than that, I took your wording.

I don't know what this is implying?  A specific language?  Does this preclude `oreboot`?

Can we just be more direct about what the implications of this are?

> I don't know what this is implying?  A specific language?  Does this preclude `oreboot`?
> 
> Can we just be more direct about what the implications of this are?

At a design level, this implies that this library implementation not take on OpenBMC-specific dependencies, and is probably written in C, but that's not really the "requirement".  The requirement is that the code can be shared in EDK2, so if there's a way to make this code fit that requirement that isn't written in C, I didn't want to preclude it in the requirements.


Full disclosure here, I'm part of the oreboot org, but I have no designs for trying to get this code shared with oreboot.

The intent behind oreboot is to use rust, so that seems incompatible at a library level with EDK2/OpenBMC.  If there's a way to write this design that includes oreboot, and there's interest from oreboot maintainers, we can certainly get this section amended.
Acknowledged
Done
I would prefer if this is also done in a way that supports heterogeneous systems (ex. blade style chassis).
Added the requirement.  PTAL.
Done
`s/eluded/alluded/`
Will fix.
Fixed.
Can we enumerate what these users are?  If it is a bunch of proprietary code, why do we care?

I don't have a good enumeration of all the users at this point, nor do I know how to list it here.

> why do we care?

Because it gives us some indication that the code as it exists is fit for form and function?  My goal was to avoid a design doc that amounted to "Please give me a blank repo.".

I fully expect that relatively few lines of the initial libcper code survives the next few years of development.
Acknowledged
Happy to chat about my experiences with C library maintenance for e.g. libpldm if that helps anyone. I think some of the things we do there could be interesting to others.

Yes please.  I fully expect that once we get libcper into a place where we can start making modifications to it (that isn't one person or companies fork), we can start having a lot of code restructuring conversations that we can't have right now.
phosphor-logging?

Adding the repo at this point I don't think involves phosphor-logging?  Yes, in a complete design, it would involve phosphor-logging, but this design is very strictly about trying to get libcper maintained and able to be contributed to.

I've added phosphor-logging here despite the above.
Acknowledged
Does this needs to be in a References section?
Generally not;  When this is rendered in github, this section dissappears.
These references were showing as a paragraph when displayed in the formatted/readable view.
Yes, @arj pointed this out too.   You've reviewed and old patchset.  Please review the latest patchset, and if you still have concerns, please let me know.
Done
Where would this code reside? Would this be in a vendor specific repo or some dir in the libcper repo itself? The proposed design doesn't mention info on this.

> Where would this code reside? 
>Would this be in a vendor specific repo or some dir in the libcper repo itself? The proposed design doesn't mention info on this.

The intent is that it would reside in this repo.  If you have concrete changes to this design doc that would make that more clear, I'm happy to add them, but I had thought that was apparent by me requesting this repository in OpenBMC.  I can't control where people outside of OpenBMC put their code or what modifications they make (nor would I want to).
Another formatting comment :)

Named references need to use square brackets, so `[UEFI Specification][cper_spec]`. Parentheses are for inline references (where you provide the URL directly).

You can see what you have results in a link in the rendering, but the URL makes no sense:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/docs/+/refs/changes/77/71577/6/designs/cper-records.md

Please audit the rest of the document and fix throughout.

I did test this on the github parser, and it renders just fine:

https://github.com/edtanous/docs/blob/cper/designs/cper-records.md

I guess I assumed that github was the markdown dialect we were using, but you're right, gitiles and github look like they do something different.  grrrrr
Wait, I misunderstood what you were saying, and github has the wrong link too.  ACK.  Will fix (tomorrow)

I think I've fixed this correctly, links work correctly on github.

https://github.com/edtanous/docs/blob/master/designs/cper-records.md

My recollection is that there are a few new dependencies that the current libcper pulls in also, which do not have recipes in upstream already.  Are those recipes going to be sent upstream or are we owning those also?

I'll submit whatever is needed to openembedded, not a big deal.  I know there was a question of the base64 implementation, which has been replaced with yet another base64 implementation in the meson-dev branch that this doc will pull.

My intent once this is somewhere we can work on it is to either pull one of the existing single-file solutions already in openbmc to replace the hard dependency, or upstream the base64 recipe to open embedded.  Base64 decoding doesn't seem like the kind of thing that's worth taking a dependency on a library for such a small piece of code

The intent is not to add any recipes aside from libcper into meta-phosphor or openbmc/openbmc.
Acknowledged
nit: Neither the spec nor Arm uses this word.  Not sure it matters since in common vernacular it is probably understandable as-is.

nit: Do you want this to be "X64/IA32, and Itanium"?  The UEFI spec treats all x86 as the same.

The spec also uses IA64 in place of Itanium, but I'm fine with the common name here.

I used the wording that Samer asked for as-is;  If I'm going to wordsmith it, i'd rather just remove the specifics and call out that it's "various architectures and instruction sets".  If that change works for you, I can make it, but i don't know how important it is to the point.
Changed to aarch64
Acknowledged
Reopening due to unresolved change suggestion.  This was a nit and I don't care too much.
Fixed again.  Thanks for the pointer.
Is Arm necessary here?
That's my requirement scope, but sure, I can remove the word arm.

I don't know if you were intending to remove ARM or not here.

Perhaps it is my misunderstanding, but I was under the impression that GPUs can also create CPER records.
Removed it.

This is not the CPER spec.  This is a link to the Arm SBR.

The UEFI spec can be found at https://uefi.org/specifications
Changed the name of the link, it might not make sense in some contexts anymore, let me re-take a look at that.
Ok, I think i got all the links differentiated between the arm sbr and the UEFI spec.
Can we make this a perma-link?
Done
There are a few comments that I had in PS7 and were marked "done" without being resolved by future patch sets.  I'm currently waiting for that to happen for my +2.
I mean +1.

I went through everything I marked done, I found two that got messed up in the patches, phosphor-dump-collector -> phosphor-debug-collector, and the permalink.  Sorry about that.  If there are more than that you see, give me a hint and I'll get them fixed.
What's the reason for phosphor-logging being in the "immediate" modification set instead of the "potential future" one?

Because I was asked to add it:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/71577/4..11/designs/cper-records.md#b88

Unless I'm misreading something, it looks to me like Patrick's comment was suggesting adding it to the latter ("Potentially in the future") list?  (Which would be more in line with what I would have expected, FWIW.)
Ah, you're right, that would make more sense.  Moved phosphor-logging to that section.
nit: "Arm server CPUs"
I'm just going to remove the word ARM
Done
"this document" should refer to the Arm SBMR spercification, which defines the IPMI RAS messages and event receiver.
This doc only covers libcper.  It doesn't cover IPMI messaging, which would be CPU specific

My feedback is about this sentence:

"Within this document there are several architecture definitions for BMC, including section C.2.2 RAS IPMI Message Format, and IPMI based RAS Event Receiver."

This looks like a reference to section C.2.2 of SBMR 2.0 specification (https://developer.arm.com/documentation/den0069/latest) . Maybe just add the [arm_sbmr] link here.
Suggesting using "arm_sbmr" instead when referencing SBMR, to avoid confusion with other Arm specifications such as SBBR and BBSR
Changed link names.
The repo has been created so we should probably merge this now?
